questions.question: What is frontend development?
options: The process of optimizing database queries
The practice of creating the user-facing part of websites and web applications
A method for backend API development
A design approach focused solely on server configurations
questions.answer: The practice of creating the user-facing part of websites and web applications
questions.explanation: Frontend development involves building the client-side interface that users see and interact with in a web browser.

questions.question: Which three core technologies form the foundation of most frontend development?
questions.answer: HTML, CSS, and JavaScript
questions.explanation: HTML structures content, CSS styles it, and JavaScript adds interactivity, forming the backbone of web frontends.

questions.question: What is HTML?
options: A programming language for server-side logic
A markup language used to structure web content
questions.answer: A markup language used to structure web content
questions.explanation: HTML (HyperText Markup Language) defines the structure and meaning of web content with elements and tags.

questions.question: What is CSS?
options: A scripting language for creating animations
A language used to style and format the layout of web pages
A backend framework for building APIs
questions.answer: A language used to style and format the layout of web pages
questions.explanation: CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) controls the presentation of HTML elements, including colors, fonts, and layout.

questions.question: What is JavaScript?
options: A programming language that runs in the browser to add interactivity
questions.answer: A programming language that runs in the browser to add interactivity
questions.explanation: JavaScript enables dynamic behavior on web pages, handling user interactions and manipulating the DOM.

questions.question: What is the Document Object Model (DOM)?
options: An API that represents the structure of a web page as a tree of objects
questions.answer: An API that represents the structure of a web page as a tree of objects
questions.explanation: The DOM lets JavaScript interact with HTML elements and attributes, enabling dynamic updates and interactivity.

questions.question: What is responsive web design?
options: Designing web pages that require manual resizing by the user
A technique to ensure web content adapts smoothly to different screen sizes and devices
A method for writing backend APIs
questions.answer: A technique to ensure web content adapts smoothly to different screen sizes and devices
questions.explanation: Responsive design uses fluid layouts, flexible images, and CSS media queries to create a good user experience on any device.

questions.question: What is a CSS framework?
options: A collection of prewritten CSS rules to speed up UI design
questions.answer: A collection of prewritten CSS rules to speed up UI design
questions.explanation: CSS frameworks like Bootstrap or Tailwind provide standardized, reusable styles and layouts for faster frontend development.

questions.question: What is a CSS preprocessor?
options: A tool that removes all CSS from a project
A tool that extends CSS with variables, functions, and nested rules, compiled into regular CSS
questions.answer: A tool that extends CSS with variables, functions, and nested rules, compiled into regular CSS
questions.explanation: Preprocessors like SASS or LESS add programming-like features to CSS, making stylesheets more maintainable.

questions.question: What is a frontend framework or library?
options: A collection of tools and patterns that simplify building complex user interfaces
questions.answer: A collection of tools and patterns that simplify building complex user interfaces
questions.explanation: Frontend frameworks/libraries like React, Angular, or Vue provide reusable components and structures for building UIs.

questions.question: What is React?
options: A JavaScript library for building user interfaces, focusing on component-based architecture
questions.answer: A JavaScript library for building user interfaces, focusing on component-based architecture
questions.explanation: React uses a virtual DOM and components to efficiently update and render UIs.

questions.question: What is Angular?
options: A TypeScript-based frontend framework by Google
questions.answer: A TypeScript-based frontend framework by Google
questions.explanation: Angular is a full-featured framework that provides a robust structure for building complex, scalable web applications.

questions.question: What is Vue.js?
options: A progressive JavaScript framework for building user interfaces
questions.answer: A progressive JavaScript framework for building user interfaces
questions.explanation: Vue.js focuses on incrementally adoptable architecture, making it easy to integrate into projects or build complex SPAs.

questions.question: What is a Single Page Application (SPA)?
options: A website that consists of only one HTML file and no JavaScript
An application that loads a single HTML page and dynamically updates it, without full page reloads
A method for version controlling code
questions.answer: An application that loads a single HTML page and dynamically updates it, without full page reloads
questions.explanation: SPAs improve user experience by using AJAX and the browser’s history API to update the page content without reloading.

questions.question: What is the box model in CSS?
options: A conceptual design model for HTML elements as boxes with content, padding, borders, and margins
questions.answer: A conceptual design model for HTML elements as boxes with content, padding, borders, and margins
questions.explanation: The box model helps understand how elements occupy space and how their sizes and spaces are computed in layouts.

questions.question: What are CSS selectors?
options: A method for rendering server-side code
Patterns used to select the HTML elements to style
questions.answer: Patterns used to select the HTML elements to style
questions.explanation: CSS selectors target elements by their tag, class, ID, attributes, or state to apply styling rules.

questions.question: What is the difference between class and ID selectors in CSS?
options: IDs are for multiple elements; classes are for single elements
IDs are unique and used once per page, classes can be applied to multiple elements
Classes are always preceded by '#' and IDs by '.'
questions.answer: IDs are unique and used once per page, classes can be applied to multiple elements
questions.explanation: An ID should be unique in a document, while classes can be reused for styling multiple similar elements.

questions.question: What is an event in JavaScript?
options: An action or occurrence detected by the browser, such as a click or key press, to which you can respond with code
questions.answer: An action or occurrence detected by the browser, such as a click or key press, to which you can respond with code
questions.explanation: Events enable interactive pages by triggering JavaScript functions when users interact with the UI.

questions.question: What are media queries?
options: Queries to fetch images from the server
CSS rules that apply styles based on device characteristics like width or orientation
questions.answer: CSS rules that apply styles based on device characteristics like width or orientation
questions.explanation: Media queries support responsive design by adjusting layouts and styles for different screen sizes.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'async' attribute in a script tag?
options: To load scripts in the background without blocking page rendering
To handle errors in CSS loading
questions.answer: To load scripts in the background without blocking page rendering
questions.explanation: Using 'async' allows the browser to download JavaScript files while the page continues to load, improving performance.

questions.question: What is AJAX?
options: A technique using JavaScript and XML/JSON to fetch data asynchronously without page reloads
questions.answer: A technique using JavaScript and XML/JSON to fetch data asynchronously without page reloads
questions.explanation: AJAX (Asynchronous JavaScript and XML) enhances user experience by updating the UI dynamically as data loads in the background.

questions.question: What is Webpack?
options: A module bundler for JavaScript applications
questions.answer: A module bundler for JavaScript applications
questions.explanation: Webpack bundles code and assets, managing dependencies and optimizing the output for production.

questions.question: What is Babel?
options: A JavaScript compiler that converts modern JS code into backward-compatible versions
questions.answer: A JavaScript compiler that converts modern JS code into backward-compatible versions
questions.explanation: Babel allows developers to use the latest JavaScript features without worrying about browser compatibility.

questions.question: What is TypeScript?
options: A superset of JavaScript that adds static typing and other features
questions.answer: A superset of JavaScript that adds static typing and other features
questions.explanation: TypeScript helps catch errors during development and makes large JavaScript codebases more maintainable.

questions.question: What is a CSS reset or normalize file?
options: A file that removes all HTML styles
A set of styles that make browsers render elements more consistently by resetting or normalizing default styles
questions.answer: A set of styles that make browsers render elements more consistently by resetting or normalizing default styles
questions.explanation: CSS resets or normalize.css reduce cross-browser inconsistencies, ensuring a more predictable styling baseline.

questions.question: What is progressive enhancement?
options: A method of continuously refactoring backend code
A strategy where core content and functionality are accessible to all, while enhanced features are available to browsers that support them
questions.answer: A strategy where core content and functionality are accessible to all, while enhanced features are available to browsers that support them
questions.explanation: Progressive enhancement ensures that basic functionality works for everyone, regardless of browser capabilities.

questions.question: What is graceful degradation?
options: Designing a site that only works on modern browsers
Starting with a complex, modern experience and ensuring it degrades nicely on older or less capable browsers
questions.answer: Starting with a complex, modern experience and ensuring it degrades nicely on older or less capable browsers
questions.explanation: Graceful degradation is the opposite approach of progressive enhancement, focusing first on modern experiences.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a polyfill?
options: To change the color of text
To provide fallback code for browser features that do not support a certain API or functionality
questions.answer: To provide fallback code for browser features that do not support a certain API or functionality
questions.explanation: Polyfills enable older browsers to run modern JavaScript features by including scripts that emulate those features.

questions.question: What is ARIA in web accessibility?
options: A set of attributes designed to make web content more accessible to people with disabilities
questions.answer: A set of attributes designed to make web content more accessible to people with disabilities
questions.explanation: WAI-ARIA attributes help screen readers and assistive technologies better interpret and interact with web content.

questions.question: What is a CSS sprite?
options: A technique to reduce HTTP requests by combining multiple images into a single file
questions.answer: A technique to reduce HTTP requests by combining multiple images into a single file
questions.explanation: CSS sprites improve performance by loading one image and using background-position to show different parts as needed.

questions.question: What is lazy loading?
options: Always loading all images and data upfront
Deferring the loading of non-critical resources (like images off-screen) until needed
A method of caching data locally
questions.answer: Deferring the loading of non-critical resources (like images off-screen) until needed
questions.explanation: Lazy loading improves performance by not loading content until the user actually needs to view it.

questions.question: What is the difference between inline, inline-block, and block-level elements in CSS?
options: Inline elements don't start on a new line, block elements do, and inline-block elements are inline but can have a set width and height
Block elements never use width and height
questions.answer: Inline elements don't start on a new line, block elements do, and inline-block elements are inline but can have a set width and height
questions.explanation: This difference affects how elements are rendered and how other elements flow around them.

questions.question: What is the CSS box-sizing property?
options: A property that sets the font size
A property that defines how the width and height of an element are calculated (content-box or border-box)
A property that controls layout of text
questions.answer: A property that defines how the width and height of an element are calculated (content-box or border-box)
questions.explanation: With box-sizing: border-box, an element’s declared width and height include padding and borders, simplifying layouts.

questions.question: What is a CSS transition?
options: An effect that smoothly changes a property’s value over a given duration
questions.answer: An effect that smoothly changes a property’s value over a given duration
questions.explanation: Transitions allow animations of CSS property changes when triggered by user interactions or state changes.

questions.question: What is a CSS animation?
options: A sequence of changes to a CSS property defined with keyframes over time
A method to store data in the browser
questions.answer: A sequence of changes to a CSS property defined with keyframes over time
questions.explanation: CSS animations use keyframes to define stages of an animation, allowing complex transitions without JavaScript.

questions.question: What is Web Accessibility?
options: Ensuring websites and tools can be used by people with disabilities
questions.answer: Ensuring websites and tools can be used by people with disabilities
questions.explanation: Accessibility involves designing and developing websites so people with disabilities can perceive, understand, navigate, and interact effectively.

questions.question: What is a Progressive Web App (PWA)?
options: A web app that uses modern capabilities (like service workers) to provide an app-like experience, offline support, and installability
questions.answer: A web app that uses modern capabilities (like service workers) to provide an app-like experience, offline support, and installability
questions.explanation: PWAs bridge the gap between web and native apps, enhancing performance and user engagement.

questions.question: What is a Service Worker?
options: A script that runs in the background of a web page, enabling features like offline caching and push notifications
questions.answer: A script that runs in the background of a web page, enabling features like offline caching and push notifications
questions.explanation: Service workers can intercept network requests, cache resources, and deliver offline experiences in PWAs.

questions.question: What is Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS)?
options: A security mechanism that controls how resources can be fetched from domains other than the one serving the page
questions.answer: A security mechanism that controls how resources can be fetched from domains other than the one serving the page
questions.explanation: CORS prevents unauthorized cross-origin requests, protecting users from malicious websites trying to access private data.

questions.question: What is the difference between '=='' and '===' in JavaScript?
options: '==' checks both value and type, '===' checks only type
'==' is used for arrays, '===' for strings
'==' converts types before comparing, '===' compares without type conversion
questions.answer: '==' converts types before comparing, '===' compares without type conversion
questions.explanation: The triple equals operator (===) checks both type and value equality, ensuring more predictable comparisons.

questions.question: What is localStorage?
options: A JavaScript feature that stores key-value data in the browser with no expiration
questions.answer: A JavaScript feature that stores key-value data in the browser with no expiration
questions.explanation: localStorage persists data even after the browser is closed, unlike sessionStorage which clears on tab close.

questions.question: What is the Shadow DOM?
options: A separate, encapsulated DOM subtree that can style and script elements without affecting the main document
questions.answer: A separate, encapsulated DOM subtree that can style and script elements without affecting the main document
questions.explanation: Shadow DOM is used in Web Components to isolate component styles and markup from the rest of the page.

questions.question: What are Web Components?
options: A set of web platform APIs for creating reusable custom elements with their own encapsulated functionality and styling
questions.answer: A set of web platform APIs for creating reusable custom elements with their own encapsulated functionality and styling
questions.explanation: Web Components allow you to define custom, reusable HTML elements with encapsulated styles and logic.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a Content Delivery Network (CDN)?
options: To store data in a local database
To serve static files (images, scripts, styles) from geographically distributed servers for faster load times
questions.answer: To serve static files (images, scripts, styles) from geographically distributed servers for faster load times
questions.explanation: CDNs improve performance and reduce latency by delivering static content from servers close to the user.

questions.question: What is Lighthouse?
options: An open-source tool by Google to audit page performance, accessibility, SEO, and best practices
questions.answer: An open-source tool by Google to audit page performance, accessibility, SEO, and best practices
questions.explanation: Lighthouse provides insights and suggestions to improve the quality of web pages.

questions.question: What are CSS variables (Custom Properties)?
options: Properties that allow reuse of values throughout a stylesheet and can be updated dynamically
questions.answer: Properties that allow reuse of values throughout a stylesheet and can be updated dynamically
questions.explanation: CSS variables make it easier to maintain consistent designs and adapt themes on the fly.

questions.question: What is the difference between 'display: none' and 'visibility: hidden' in CSS?
options: 'display: none' removes the element from layout; 'visibility: hidden' hides it but leaves space
'display: none' makes element transparent; 'visibility: hidden' changes color to white
'visibility: hidden' removes the element from the DOM
questions.answer: 'display: none' removes the element from layout; 'visibility: hidden' hides it but leaves space
questions.explanation: display: none completely removes the element from the flow, visibility: hidden leaves an empty space.

questions.question: What is the purpose of 'defer' attribute in a script tag?
options: To ensure the script executes after the HTML is fully parsed but before DOMContentLoaded event
questions.answer: To ensure the script executes after the HTML is fully parsed but before DOMContentLoaded event
questions.explanation: Scripts with 'defer' don't block HTML parsing and run in the order they appear once the document is parsed.

questions.question: What is Cross-Browser Compatibility?
options: Making sure the website uses only one browser
Ensuring a web application works as intended across different web browsers
A feature of a CSS framework
questions.answer: Ensuring a web application works as intended across different web browsers
questions.explanation: Cross-browser compatibility is crucial so that users get a consistent experience regardless of their browser choice.

questions.question: What is Server-Side Rendering (SSR)?
options: A method where the initial HTML of a page is generated on the server, improving load performance and SEO
questions.answer: A method where the initial HTML of a page is generated on the server, improving load performance and SEO
questions.explanation: SSR sends a fully rendered page from the server, resulting in better performance and SEO than client-only rendering.
